title: Question 249

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for the gradual onset of visual impairment over a period of 6 months. She has no other symptoms, including headache, pain with eye movement, seeing halos around lights, or photopsia.

Neurologic examination is otherwise normal. Confrontation testing shows diminished vision in the temporal fields. Formal visual field testing confirms this finding and ascertains that she has normal central visual acuity.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Bitemporal hemianopsia is most commonly caused by compression of the optic chiasm due to a sellar mass.
Patients suspected of having a sellar mass should be referred for pituitary MRI with gadolinium contrast.
The most likely diagnosis is a pituitary adenoma (

) in this patient with bitemporal hemianopsia, which is most commonly caused by compression of the optic chiasm due to a sellar mass. Pituitary adenomas are the most common cause of sellar masses. The onset of the visual field defect with a sellar mass is typically gradual. Patients suspected of having a sellar mass should be referred for pituitary MRI with gadolinium contrast. MRI can differentiate between pituitary hemorrhage and a sellar mass, and it can define the relationship between the mass and surrounding tissues.

) is a progressive chronic disease involving the central retina. Patients with early AMD are often asymptomatic, although yellow drusen may be visible underneath retinal pigment epithelium. Patients with atrophic AMD, which accounts for 80% to 90% of AMD cases, note slowly progressive vision loss over years. AMD does not cause bitemporal hemianopsia and this patient has normal central vision, excluding the diagnosis of AMD.

) commonly causes optic neuritis and/or eye movement abnormalities. Optic neuritis typically presents with unilateral eye pain that is worsened with eye movements and the presence of photopsia (flashing lights) and/or visual loss affecting central vision. Eye movement abnormalities in multiple sclerosis include abnormalities of voluntary gaze and nystagmus. These abnormalities present as diplopia or oscillopsia. Multiple sclerosis does not commonly affect the optic chiasm.

A rapidly growing pituitary tumor or rapid expansion due to pituitary apoplexy (sudden hemorrhage or infarction of a pituitary adenoma) causing compression of the optic chiasm may result in complete bitemporal hemianopsia or even blindness. Pituitary apoplexy may even result in cranial nerve palsies of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI, whereas a slowly growing pituitary tumor that abuts the optic chiasm may cause minimal or no loss in peripheral vision.
